title: Connecting Professional Skill Demand with Supply

author: Erik Novak, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: So my name is Eric Novak and I'm going to present our work on connecting professional skill demand with supply, and this work was done also in collaboration with with my colleague in an overly artificial intelligence laboratory.
So let's start with the.

Ovation of this work so different when a person is applying for a job he normally first looks at the job description for the job that he's interested in and that job description, the skills that are required for that position can be described or also can be omitted, so that's not the whole skill set is available on the description and based on this skill set the person that is applying for the job.
He needs to.

He needs to either he either has this curious or either needs to acquire it by by enrolling into different courses, or by learning from different learning materials and finding the correct or the appropriate courses and learning materials can be tedious, and that's where our work got the motivation.
So in this paper are goals that we set are the detect professional skills required on the job market.
And then also to analyze the evolution of the required skills and recommend appropriate learning materials.
Here we focus more mostly on job postings that are in some relationship with data science.
But this whole methodology and the whole whole workflow can be used also for different other fields and other topics.

And this job postings contain normally contain the title of the position, the organization, the description.
And also other information and then for the courses that we are interested in the lectures we targeted different different data providers for the courses we targeted.
Acknowledged data providers such as Coursera, hacker, IO Futurelearn and others.
And for lectures we targeted videolectures.net which is one of the largest video repository's on the website.

So to acquire these data, some of these services have their dedicated API which were used to acquire this data, but for others that did not have this API we created custom crawlers which scraped on their websites to get the information that we are interested in.
After we got the data we have, we send the data for the enrichment process.
The first step in the nourishment process is the verification which is linking.
Which is linking textual components with the Wikipedia pages and we used wiki fire service that was presented earlier today.
Next time with this process, we also because of the weak fire com supports crossing multi lingual Merton equality.
Or you can also get different Wikipedia concepts in different languages.
Next we extracted skills using.

This are ontologies are ontologies, ontology that has the skill and recruitment which is a skill and recruitment ontology and contains the different skills that are targeted for data science and what we did here is for each job posting course in lecture we went.
We checked if the wikifeet Wikipedia concepts match with some of the.
Of the.
Skills that are found in ontology and if there is a match, that concept became the data science skill.
And third, the third step of the enrichment is extracting locations an countries using Geonames ontology, and doing this.
We got additional ability to.
NYS job postings by their different locations and countries so that we can also look as a subset of these job postings.
